Tsumiki is the legit female lead and well she has a thing for Io but she cant get her self to really say anything to him and also the fact she is a tsundere kinda hurts her with telling him as well overall shes a kinda shy character but really friendly unless you get on her side when you try to get to Io. Mayoi is a another lead character she is really the tech person of the anime so does a lot of ambitious stuff that be either creating stuff or saying stuff that ends up Tsumiki whaling on her (or just getting punched by Tsumiki) otherwise a pretty up and going character with jokes for sure. Story: The plot of Acchi Kocchi mimics the pace of the notorious Lucky Star, the slow but enjoyable pace that leaves the viewer satisfied with the slice-of-life theme and craving for more the next week. Each week left me with laughs and simple morals like friendship and comedy are important in life. It has been a while since there has been such an anime with a refine storyline and plot. In my own opinion, this show rivals Bleach, Naruto, One Piece and all the rest that overdo the lenght of the story. Sometimes simple and funny is the best way to appeal to the viewer.Although this show may be overlook due to shows that are popular today. I loved ever minute of each episode, except for the finale, which sort of went a different direction that I was anticipation. Aside from that I strongly recommend this show to anyone. 


Art: How do I put this? The Art is undeniably incredible. The simplicity of the art reflects the theme of "Slice-of-life" which most shows try to create with their own style. The Art is comparable to Lucky Star. I for one love the simplicity and would love more shows to have the same style of artwork.


Sound: The dialogue and BMG are outstanding and would not have it any other way.


Character: The characters compliment each other as each of them have a specific role that the cover for the comic relief. 


Enjoyment: 10


Overall: This is a show that will leave you with the thought of Io and Tsumiki and how their relationship grows as each episode passes. I would LOVE if the made a season 2, but sometimes there are things that are better left in one awesome season filled comedy, thrills and love that friends love to pick on.

I have seen the manga before and thus have come to expect the anime to be equally enjoyable. So far the impressions have been relatively positive. However,the reason why I'm writing this review is because other reviewers have expressed their views so far and I got this "err, not exactly the ratings I'd like to see" feeling. Please don't get me wrong, I'm a big sucker for slice of life anime and this one just hits the sweet spot for me, but as I'm trying to let other people know about the anime I feel that I should be as objective as possible in givingmy ratings. 


And without further ado:


Story: 6

Slice of life anime's Achilles heel is definitely the story. Acchi Kocchi by itself is no exception. The plot revolves around a close group of friends in high school and how they spend their daily lives in school, getting involved in idiotic-but-cute activities and...romance. The plot, like usual with slice of life anime, is a matter of hit or miss. While its relaxing and laid back nature might be more than adequate for fan of the genre, people who are looking for more serious and elaborate storyline should make their choice elsewhere.


Characters: 8

Like the other reviewer has said, the cast of Acchi Kocchi is a combination of cliched archetype characters. From the more dere than tsun Tsumiki to the cool and composed Io, the slightly perverted sidekick Sakaki, the wacky, mad scientist Mayoi and the othodox klutz Hime...individually, they are not that great, but when put in such settings, actually prove to synergize well with others. How could someone not enjoy the sight of Io and Tsumiki getting into a romantic sittuation, only to be sabotaged by the deliberate third-wheel combo Sakaki and Mayoi, while having Hime nosebleed like a mini fountain in complement? I also found that this character combination helps prevent the romance from being overly "warm" and mushy-gushy, retaining the easygoing mood for the show. 


Art: 8

The cutesy art in Acchi Kocchi, while nothing extraordinary taken out of context, seems to work well with the other elements. Characters and scenery are well polished and portrayed in a manner that extremely helps in describing the carefree and heartwarming atmosphere of the show.The combination of Tsumiki's various expressions (including the cat ears that occasionally pop out), Mayoi's catlike upper lip, the arrow transitions, etc... gives the show an unique touch and distinguishes it with others of the same genre (Hime could do with a bit less of nosebleed though :3 ).


Sound: 9

Really great voice acting here! Tsumiki's tsundere shyness, Io's composure and calmness, Mayoi's wackiness...are all absolutely well expressed. It gives me the feeling that the voice acting has been carefully considered, and if you don't mind, tailored to give such excellent result. Also, the OP and ED, while do not sound terribly brilliant, are cute (sounds like the perfect word to describe the series) and catchy nonetheless.


Enjoyment: 9

Enjoyment, when it comes to specific show and different individuals, has always been a matter of "your mileage might vary". Specifically, I wholeheartedly enjoy the show despite its obvious plot drawback since that works for me. Putting aside all the complicated stuff, watching anime to me is simply to put a smile on my face and make me happy, and as another reviewer has also said, this season I have a reason to look forward to Friday.


Overall: 8

If complicated story, awesome fighting scenes and wonderfully designed characters are what you're looking for, then I'm sorry to say but you probably would not fare too far with Acchi Kocchi. But if you're the same as me, seeking for your slice of life fill of the season with cute characters, heartwarming atmosphere and a touch of comedy, then this one is undoubtedly for you.

You know, if we could choose the way we could die, that would be interesting, how would I?
Death by cuteness.
Acchi Kocchi, was quite a surprise to me, I thought at first it would just be a cutesy, slice-of-life, anime with a little bit of romance mixed in....I was wrong.
I mean it IS very cute, I almost died from the first episode, but....
It's a bit more unique than that. If you like Nichijou (We pretty much we all do) then you will like Acchi Kocchi. It's similar enough to Nichijou that it's enjoyable, but not so similar that it's a ripoff.
Acchi Kocchi is kinda like atamer version of Nichijou, but it's still good.

Acchi Kocchi has a simplistic art style like Nichijou, but it also has a myriad of beautiful effects that makes it appealing, like Nichijou. Also some pretty NOT slice of life things happen.


Like that pretty much all the characters have superhuman strength at some point (Except Hime)

or at least ridiculous sport skills (or pen twirling)

Or how everything gravitates toward Sakaki, to hit the poor guy.


The comedy is actually pretty good, but romance wise...eh.

Don't come here looking for romance, I mean yeah Io and Tsumiki look adorable together, but at the end, nothing progressed between them..


But i'm sure both of them know deep down, they're like this:


"We're a thing"


So I'll just leave it at that.

All the voice actors are good, and the music will probably either grow on you, or annoy you.

But all in all I think it's an adorable comedy and I highly recommend if you like Nichijou.

I wish I had my own pet Tsumiki, and Io's amazing pen spinning skills.


Thank you for reading my review!

I gave this anime a try today and it was SO CUTE! So there's not much plot and it's a bit random at times but if you are like me and enjoy some brainless episodes about everyday life, you would like it too. AND not to mention, the main female character is super adorable! Her little cute antics and her kind of obvious attraction for her stoic friend keeps you wondering how she's going to react next. 
If you prefer serious stories and intense storylines, this might not be the anime for you. But if you love cute things, here's a treat for you~

The best way to describe Acchi Kocchi in a few words is: fluffy relaxation. At least that's how it felt for me. This is the kind of anime that just makes you fell all warm and cuddly inside. So it might not be for everyone. If you are looking for drama or serious conflict this is not the anime for you, but if you want to just melt in your chair and get a smile over your face for a few hours watch it! 
Story 6/10: Seeing how this is a slice of life rom-com about a girl who likes a boy set in aschool environment, there isn't much of a story to talk about. Shy girl like boy acts all cutesy and stuff, that's all you need to know. 


Art 7/10: The art is nothing to brag about but it's enough for this type of anime. Some might complain about the lack of proper textures of most people except for the main characters but you only need to see the main characters and the interactions between them. Plus the textures on the rest of the people can be looked at as artistic. 


Sound 7/10:  The sound is ok with a rare or to my knowledge unique intro it's uniqueness coming from the fact that it's a duet. It's cheerful and energetic, maybe to energetic, compared to the pace of the anime which is more lax. 


Characters 7/10: The characters are all interesting and funny but the main attraction is Tsumiki, the female lead who is just the cutest thing ever. And by that I don't mean only looks, her interactions and her personality just makes you want to pat her and protect her like a cute little cat. 


Enjoyment  9/10: I really enjoyed this anime. I realize it might not be everyone's cup of tea but if you feel the need for something heart warming from time to time, an anime like this is the best thing! For some people it might just have to much cuteness and fluffiness but it really put a smile on my face throughout the hole thing. 


Overall 7/10: Trying to be as objective as possible I will give this anime a 7 but I totally recommend it. If you enjoy bathing it a tone of cuteness from time to time, go watch this anime, you will not be disappointed.

Acchi Kocchi: Is an anime called 'Place to Place', and to be frank, the title suits it perfectly. There is no major storyline or plot, but rather, a cute, fun and hilarious anime about the daily life of two cute high school lovers, their friends and adventures, that will leave you with a big smile on your face and wanting more.
Art: 9/10 Cute, humble and enjoyable, it wasn't drastic or very graphical, but for a comedic romance like this, it suited the mood, characters and story perfectly. 
Story: 8/10: There wasn't really a story in Acchi Kocchi, but with characters this cute, who needed one,there wasn't an antagonist or major problems that caused rifts inbetween the friendships or lovers, it was simply two highschool lovers, their lives, their friends, and their adventures.


Sound: 9/:10: Music, was generally happy, lively and enjoyable, there never a moment where the music would upset or contrast with the mood or atmosphere.


Characters:10/10: The standout of this series, the characters were made brilliantly, and each were genuine in their own way. Sasaki and Mayoi the mischievous duo, Hime the cute and cuddly friend, made up the main supporting characters. Whilst Io and Tsumiki made together the best couple ever. Every supporting or main character had a pleasant or recognizable role in this anime, and reappeared throughout the series, adding much enjoyment. 


Enjoyment & Overall: 9/10: Sure it killed time, but it was a 'cutsie' anime like no other, a gem and a pleasure to watch. Acchi Kocchi did leave me wanting more, wanting further development between the main and supporting characters and their adventures. However, it left a warm fuzzy feeling within me, a happy person, and thus, it was an amazingly enjoyable anime.

Acchi Kocchi is fun little slice of life anime that features a colorful cast of characters and silly scenarios. It is one of only a few series that have made me laugh out loud. I enjoyed it from beginning to end. It doesn't really have a story. Instead, it covers the shenanigans of a group of school friends, from making Valentine's chocolate to playing games and pulling pranks. It's chock full of cuteness, nosebleeds and also has some romance. If you're looking for something lighthearted and fluffy, Acchi Kocchi delivers.

Acchi Kocchi is one of those heart-warming animes; you come home from a harsh and tiresome day at school or work, tired and stressed you make coffee, sit in front of your PC or laptop and turn to Acchi Kocchi, shortly after which all your problems dissipate and then you've suddenly turned into a warm marshmallow of happiness and coziness. 
Judging from the cover, I simply came to the conclusion that Acchi Kocchi would be one of those cliche SoL/RomCom animes but boy was I wrong! The jokes were quite refreshing though there were some few jokes I totally saw coming. Each episode was filledwith warm fuzzy happiness along with jokes that were perfectly pulled off.


Plot: 7

Since this is a SoL anime, you can't expect an extraordinary over-the-top plot. Rather than that, it has a simple plot that people of all ages(bet even 2 year olds) can understand. The anime is about a group of high schoolers and their daily lives. It also frequently inserts cute scenes mainly consisting of Io........where, if you're a girl, you're bound to lose your senses and pass out. The jokes in this anime, as I view them, are chuckle or giggle material though there are certain hilarious scenes that made me rofl(literally). 


Art: 9

The art was the main reason I was drawn to watching this anime. The art really suited the anime and its atmosphere. The art kinda reminded me of Lucky Star and K-On(Dunno why it reminded me of the latter). It was consistent throughout the entire series and I love consistent art~ The chibi scenes were really cute and really suited the anime.


Sound: 8

First of all, the OP was super-duper cute, even cuter when you understand the lyrics!! The OST were soothing and relaxing, and blended really well with the scenes. My personal favorite would be 'Washa Washa', I just simply love the soothing vibe it gives off. The voice acting in this anime was superb and their voice really brought out the characters. And concluding every episode, we have a cutesy IoxTsumiku ED by Tsumiki's seiyuu. 'Te o Gyu Shite ne' is love, it is life.


Character: 9

The characters were all unique- The tsundere loved by all, Tsumiki with her frequent 'Neko' glares and cute dialogues. Our handsome male protagonist, Io with his pen-spinning top notch accuracy and out of this world smile. The airhead Hime with a nosebleed pretty much every time something cute happens between Io and Tsumiki or Io sends out his lovely smile. Our comedic duo(and 'M's), Mayoi and Sakaki; without these two I don't think the show would be complete.......though that can also be said for the entire cast.

The other characters besides our main cast are all so interesting as well, I truly wish for such a circle of friends~


Enjoyment: 9

I thoroughly enjoyed this anime and loved every single second of it. It left me with butterflies in my stomach, yearning for a high-school life such as in this anime. I personally think that 12 episodes were just not enough. The show was not only enjoyable, it was a 25 minutes escape from reality and really soothed the depressed and stressed heart.


Overall: 9

Overall, I loved and really enjoyed this anime. It'll always occupy a special place in my heart. Even you've finished the anime once or twice, it's always re-watchable so don't worry if you're about to finish it for the first time. If you can spare a day or so of the series your watching right now for Acchi Kocchi, I'm 101% sure you won't regret it. Seems I won't be forgetting this anime any time soon.

Story -7-
The story of Acchi Kocchi is one that follows a different plot every half episode, while also staying connected with the different stories. The overarching storyline, however, is the little romance that is slowly growing between Tsumiki and Io. The whole feel of the series is light and cheerful, but also gives a few moments where Tsumiki and Io can feel very close and bring out a reaction from the audience.
Since this series does not have any deep messages, nor was the plot anything too special it does not rate all that high. However, it was able to keep continuity and keep the audienceengaged. The short gags that they did also connect as most of the gags were due to certain traits from different characters. With this, one would be able to see a repeated gag whenever that character would show their tick, such as Io being excellent at spinning whatever was in his hands, be a pen, pencil, or a pair of chopsticks.


Art -7-

The art style of Acchi Kocchi is very palatable, and nothing overly special. With the pastel colors and very ‘chibi’ like drawings, the anime is easy to appeal to a middle-high school audience. There is also much use of hiragana to make it easier for the audience to feel relaxed. The use of very simple facial reactions made it so the different reactions of the cast were well received as well.

The main gag in the series is that Tsumiki’s reactions are always in reference to how a cat acts. Thankfully the anime can pull it off very well, as it could have been incredibly painful to watch if it had been done the wrong way. However, since it was done correctly, it was funny and also rather cute to see the reactions Tsumiki had, along with the other characters.


Sound -7-

The voice acting in the series was rather spot on. Each one of the characters could fully portray their personality through how they spoke. Also, they were able to hit quite a few gags due to how fast they were able to keep the thing going. The little side remarks or small sound effects the voice actors would do fully brought each character to life.

The opening and closing themes were also enjoyable as they fit the mood of the anime as a whole. The opening theme was a lot more upbeat and worked in the anime’s favor of trying to get the audience excited to watch. The closing theme wound everyone down, returning the attention to the over-arching plot of how Tsumiki wanted to be in a relationship with Io. Over all, the sound was able to keep the whole series rather nicely wrapped up.


Character -9-

Slice of life animes needs to have strong characters. Otherwise, they will fall flat and will be boring to watch; it will be pretty unentertaining to be blunt. That being said, the characters in Acchi Kocchi were extremely enduring and funny to watch. Tsumiki was adorable to watch in her attempts to try and express to Io how she was feeling, while Io was, while rather deadpan, an amazing friend. It was not hard to see why Tsumiki liked him, unlike in some animes where it is a mystery as to why the main character likes someone else.

Along with the two main characters, the side characters were also entertaining. Mayoi was always able to lighten the mood with one of her crazy inventions, or with teasing her best friend about her crush. Sakaki, while he was not in as many episodes once the series started to get rolling, was still rather funny whenever he would appear. Slap-stick humor is sometimes hard to pull off, as if it’s done wrong, the audience just feels sorry for the victim. However, Sakaki, the main victim of the physical humor, was always able to make the joke pull through. Overall, the characters of Acchi Kocchi were just an absolute pleasure to watch.


Enjoyment -8-

Slice-of-life anime is all rather similar, as the category isn’t one that’s supposed to fluctuate all that often. However, the enjoyment of Acchi Kocchi was a rather pleasant surprise. Following the main characters through a full year of their lives, the audience can see as they start to grow as people. Not only are they honest and hardworking, but they also know how to have fun and relax once they no longer have classes. It brings up memories of having to study for those days where it feels impossible to do so, the feeling of having a job and knowing the reasonability that one has.

One of the best moments of the series is near the end, where valentine’s day shows up again, as it had done in the 2nd episode. This repeat shows how Tsumiki and Io have grown in affection for each other, as Tsumiki makes chocolates that are special for just Io; Io returning the favor by putting a special treat in his gift to her. It warms the audience’s heart, ending the series with a feeling that those two will be all right, whatever happens.


Overall -7.6-

Acchi Kocchi is a nice anime just to sit down and watch a few episodes. By the end of the series, there is a warm feeling, knowing that the main characters will be okay, with fond memories of the past, and the sense of one’s first love. The pastel coloring and well-done voice acting will keep the anime in a good light. There isn’t anything too bad to say about the anime, as it is an excellent series, but it isn’t anything too amazing.

It was not trying to be an outstanding anime, as its main goal was just trying to be a small series to consume and be satisfied with. While some of the gags may not make you laugh, and sometimes it can be a bit over the top, Acchi Kocchi will compel the viewer to finish. Even if they do not like the genre all that much, it’s a feel good anime that anyone feeling down on their luck should give a try.

Acchi Kocchi is a fairly good comedy that is based on everyday things. The show does follow the basic anime forumlas (school, home-visits, beach, swimming etc..) but does it in a little more classy way.
~Story~ 5/10
There really isn't much of a story. The premise is pretty much the same as other random comedy shows, but has lots of romantic over-tones.
Tsumiki has a big crush on Io, but has no guts to say so or to confess to him. So, the other members of their group picks on her and sets her up with lots of romantic opportunities.
Overall, the show focuses mostly on random comedy thathappens on an everyday basis.\n\n
~Art~ 7/10\n
The art was great, it was mostly consistent, but there were times that cat-ears would suddenly appear and cut-aways were very frequent.\n
Nose-bleeds were rampant and happened almost every 3 minutes.\n\n
~Sound~ 7/10\n
The intro music and background music for the entire show was great. The voice acting was as expected from a comedy show.\n
However, I didn't like how the characters often had lines describing what the viewer is actually seeing. As an American I am lost to some foreign comedy, but I understood Acchi Kocchi very well and enjoyed it thoroughly without needing the characters telling me what I'm seeing.\n
Another minor thing about the voice acting is that it seemed very robotic and overly simplified.\n
I suppose that is more of a writing/scripting problem rather than a voice acting one.\n\n
~Character~ 6/10\n
There wasn't much character development, but what development did happen was focused on Tsumiki and Io.\n
The gang is your ordinary comedy group. There is a super-short and strong character (Tsumiki), the stoic and quiet (Io), there is a klutz (Hime), the brainy scientist (Mayoi) and energetic supporting male character (Sakaki).\n
They all mix and match well.\n\n
Overall I really enjoyed the show. The comedy was great and the formulas were predictable, but I truly enjoyed watching this.\n
Now, I'm off to find more like it.

Sometimes it's fruitful to take a step back and examine the basic workings of what we have come to accept. Like taking apart a cheeseburger to see just exactly what's in it and how much effort actually went into making it. Acchi Kocchi is a romantic-comedy without a gimmick. No dumb vampire lore, no petty revenge plot, no bullshit gynophobia problems, just she likes him, and she's koi about it and BAM! There's your anime.
Acchi Kocchi is the story of Tsumiki struggling to confess her crush on her friend Io. That's it. That's the whole extent of the plot. It presents itself as a sortof slice of life way, and that works pretty well. Tsumiki is a well defined character, and her shyness card is not the only one in her deck. She feels more like an actual human being, rather than a marionette going through the motions of a romcom. She takes herself seriously, and is incredibly strong, and yet she still lets her feminine side out whenever she can. Now, I have said before that I have a weakness for shy characters, and now is as good a time as any to explain why. Basically, there are three reasons. 1: I feel shyness is a good place to start to build character development. There are many ways to characterize shyness, whether it be eventually drawing them out or even just understanding what they're shy about. It presents a slew of never ending possibilities. 2: Shyness is a very relateable trait for many people, including myself. Most people have been shy in any number of situations, and I feel close to shy characters because I'm not very good at approaching people I don't know, or even people I do know at some times. 3: THEY'RE SO ADORABLE! Tsumiki provides great examples of all three. Her shyness characterizes her greatly, I could relate to her problems very well and SHE'S SO ADORABLE! Needless to say, she's the best character of the show.


The rest of the cast is pretty good too. Io is the oblivious love interest of the show. I will say, his characterization is slow going, but around episode 5 or 6 I think, his characterization gets really good and is characterized outside of an oblivious cool person who could get any girl he wants. Their friends are also pretty well-developed to the extent that they need to be as well. Hime is the confused nice girl who finds cuteness in anything she can. Sakaki is the guy who's all talk but is pretty much the buttmonkey of the whole group. Mayoi is the strange, enigmatic inventor of the group and the buttmonkey runner-up. Those three provide a good chunk of the humor in the series and they're all likeable to at least some extent.


The art is pretty good, but I feel it could have been better. It's not bad, I just feel it's trying too hard. The art is interestingly light and fluffy, but also just a tad unreal. I feel the art could have tried harder a little bit. It's still good and interesting and all, but it needs work.


The music does a good job fitting the mood. It matches the mood of the scene just right. It's nice and slow when it wants us to take it seriously, and it gets all loud and bombastic whenever something funny happens. Though, the opening is kind of not fitting. It's goofy and pop-y and just doesn't seem to match the show all the way. It's a good song, but I think the effort was mis-placed. The ending theme is very good though. It's nice, soft, and relaxing, just what you'd expect from this.


As for the voices, they do a great job at bringing out what we love about the cast. For each emotion that these characters have, the voice-actor finds a voice suitable for it. Everyone is perfectly cast and performs their character excellently.


The humor of the show is what I really like about Acchi Kocchi. It has some very great lively subtle humor. That portion of humor directly stems from the crush that Tsumiki has on Io. It's both adorable and really hilarious. However, Acchi Kocchi also has some humor that's about as subtle as a drunk clown at a rave. I think they could have used less of that though, and focus more on the subtle humor of it all. Still, to its credit, the non-subtle humor is still funny and doesn't take away from the subtle humor, and it does give Hime, Sakaki, and Mayoi more characterization. I think they focused more on that kind of humor because the creators weren't sure that the subtle humor alone could draw in as many viewers, and that's understandable. No matter what it is, there's always at least one member of the audience that can't understand something more complex than throwing a pie at someone's face, and designing something to draw in more of an audience is understandable, and it works in this case because it doesn't ruin any of the subtle humor that not everyone understands. The humor is very funny in either area and enjoyable.


Overall: Acchi Kocchi is a very good anime. The characters are great, the humor is funny, the production values are splendid and it's an overall enjoyable experience.  It does have some flaws, but the good outweighs the bad tenfold. 8/10

The first thing I'll say about this anime is that it's very neutral. 
It's your basic slice of life with a little romance and a lot of humor. I had first picked this anime to give me something safe to watch at work while I was on lunch. It cute and is a slow-paced kind of show.
I would say it's like Luck Star minus the otaku references. 
This show's highlight would have to be it's slow going romance and cat-themed style.
If you're looking for an easy going anime then this is perfect.

You know when you have practically nothing to do and want to watch an anime, probably comedy to have some laugh, and don't know that to watch? Then I will definitely recommend this anime: Acchi Kocchi (Here and there) to have a watch.
Welllll, to be honest, I thought this show is going to be pretty bad (Below 5) due to its Moe-Drawing style and it somewhat looks like Lucky-Star. However, it actually had something more that I did not expect to get from this show; which was 'Tsundere + Oblivious's romance story. 
My favourite bits from this anime was the character structure. With only 12episodes, the writer was able to input the personas of each character to us viewer and feel somewhat close to the characters. Furthermore, the Tsukkomi (punchline) in this anime was so funny I was laughing my butt off.\n\n
If you want to watch a light hearted comedy show (Even if you hate romance, I will recommend this to you), have a go!\n\n
Sayonara~

Just like the anime and the way it delivers things, this review will also be pretty simple on the matter. It also contains spoilers at random points and I was too lazy to write up warnings, mainly cause it's a comedy anime anyway. I will make sure to avoid spoiling the more majorly funny parts about it, though.
Now, Acchi Kocchi. If you are looking for an anime that has zero cliché, this anime will feel right at home in the best possible way. Its comedy is quick, yet humorous. Its love story is portrayed hilariously well and the overall enjoyment you have in this animewill be at an all-time high. For its short run, I feel like they knew they had a short amount of time to work with and aimed to fill every episode with nothing but solid comedy.


It's a skit anime, something that normally only gives you a few laughs from time to time. However, this one gives you a laugh in nearly EVERY scene you watch of it. Never will you feel like this anime is boring you because it honestly would have trouble boring anyone, even somebody that hates the medium. From start to finish, its flow is always the same and the only real development is between the two main characters that the anime heavily advertises.


However, it does not feel like a harem at all. Yes, there is a majority of girls, but there are two guys and the amount of girls is only one more than the amount of guys; counting every character from not only main, but recurring ones as well, there are a total of five females and three guys, so it still balances out rather well. 


Though, I am only counting students here, cause you actually rarely see the adults where I can only put them in the minor category; and for an anime of twelve episodes, that means they basically do not show up at all. And yes, sadly, if you never watched a harem, some do pair up the high school student with adults at times. If you are into that stuff, it is not a problem of  course. Just some free hentai! Ha, just kidding, nothing usually happens anyway when that scenario actually IS in play cause the plot is usually the male pervert, or even innocent, usually being scolded by them anyway.


In an actual harem, all of the girls are usually main characters, so that is why I can not call this a harem in the slightest at all, in that only three of the girls are main characters and all they do is entertain the audience, rather than drooling over the main boy.


In defense, though, the main boy DOES deliver his romantic lines, alongside doing other noble things, well enough to give two of the main girls nosebleeds a lot; probably the only real cliché that this anime has, though two of the girls are not madly in love with him anyway. And it happens quite often, too.


It's always funny whenever it does happen, though, so you will probably never grow bored of it. Outside that, the main boy is basically portrayed as Mr. Perfect and has a lot of unique talents, skills and has a rational sense of thinking. So, there is NO way you could ever call this a harem even if you tried your hardest. He is just a generally good character and it is very rare to actually see a comedy where they not only threw in male leads, but actually made them saints. It reminds us that not all males are perverted.


Now, his friend on the other hand...at the very most, is still just hilarious and funny. So, nope, he is not a pervert, either. His delivery of comedy is pretty good as well and he does become the butt of some jokes in a few episodes, which is handled very well. He also thinks quite rationally at times, but not as much as the other one.


As for the females, you have one that is down to earth so that the anime has some normal balance to it, complete with generic brunette hairstyle that actually IS a natural hair color. Okay, actually, two more of the females do have natural hair colors, too. Her purpose is to just have a normal opinion on the absurdity that the anime is and it is quite funny as the end result. She has the most contrast from everyone, but only in that she is the most normal of all of them. She actually is one of the main characters, so you will see her every episode.


The other two could honestly be paired up with the two males due to lacking any noticeable differences from them. Two of them think rationally and have special talents that the others don't, well the other two aim to entertain the audience in the most original fashion possible. They make the characters so obviously similar that you would not pair anyone else up with them; and yet, they also are opposites in a few ways as well that gives you all the more reason to ship them. And, I do not want to describe their characters because they are too good where I'd rather you watch them in action yourself.


My only negativities of this anime strive from the romance finale being a bit disappointing, especially when you watch the episode before it that hinted at something much more serious about to go down with the two characters. Though, in spite of this, the finale episode was the most serious of the entire anime and does actually turn it into a pretty casual Slice of Life with balanced comedy and drama as it progresses. However, I am just going to call what happened at the end a "kiss" since I do not know what else to call it. It was still heartwarming and sweet, though.


Also, well its English name makes sense ("Place to Place") as it implies that the comedy is always on the go, and I believe that is the translation of the anime name in general, I just like calling it Acchi Kocchi.


Oh, and unfortunately it does have just ONE cliché, but it still does it in an original fashion. As you know, a MAJORITY of comedy anime usually use cats as a plot device for the comedy, and Acchi Kocchi follows this standard yet again with a few characters.


Firstly, the main female lead. Instead of her having them on her head all the time, they only come out whenever she is expressing more emotion than usual; which is funny since it doesn't leave them on her the whole time like most cat cliché anime comedies do to be funny, or whenever the girl reacts just a little.


The other most notable female lead also usually ends her sentences with the Japanese terms for cat noises. In most cases, the way she times it and how she pronounces it are actually quite hilarious. So, again, reinventing anime cliché done right once more.


Lastly, one recurring character has her hair in the obvious shape of sprouting cat ears, which are on her head all of the time. However, unlike the main female lead, they do not look like obvious cat ears (yes, I am implying that the main female lead's do and actually move as such as well) and, rather, just looks like her hair was shaped like them. They never move or anything, and she never makes cat noises, so it is more of a visual sight that you would only notice if you are familiar with anime. They are about half the size of how big they normally look as well.


But, yeah, I barely put any depth in this review because I did want to avoid spoiling anything, even the NAMES. That being said, a lot of my reviews have been lacking depth lately, so I will try to fix that when I review something that has the depth for me to analyze it with a more insightful approach, cause it has been a while since I had one that had a ton of effort into it due to my interest being mostly into comedies.


Anyway, Acchi Kocchi does comedy again like most in its genre do, but I give it such a high rating because its delivery of comedy is very original; and I do not want to go on about that to avoid spoiling the experience for you, even though I already did a bit earlier.


It is something where, if you decide to watch it, you will not be upset that you did at all. At the very least, you would still be above average on your opinion about this anime, cause neutral or anything below just means you do not enjoy anime or comedies for that matter. It would take a very hateful person to truly dislike this one, let alone feel neutral about it.

Have you ever wondered to yourself: "What is too much moe?"? If so, there's your answer. THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS TOO MUCH MOE.
This show will give you diabetes from how cute it is. Even if you're not into this sort of anime (I'm personally not so much) You'll like this show.
It doesn't have a real story, just an adorable loli (not sexualised, finally) trying to get out of the friendzone while sometimes acting a bit like a tsundere (But in a cute way. Believe me, I hate tsunderes, but she's so lovable).
In terms of characters, this show doesn't accels in it's depth/characterdevelopment. It's just the regular friends hanging out and that's it. Nothing more. Of course all of the girls like the mc and get a nosebleeed every five seconds because of him, but still. Their all cute and none of the characters makes me want to serious-punch them right in the face (I'm looking at you Louise from Zero no Tsukaima.......).\n\n
The artstyle is decent, maybe slightly above average. it constantly jumps from cute-chibi style to normal style (Which is also cute), and I personally like it. It really suits to the whole style of this show. Which is of course, CUTE.\n\n
The music is actually fairly good because it matches the show's theme PERFECTLY. The opening and ending alone are awesome and really fit in with the whole "cute" vibe this show has.\n\n
Overall, I really enjoyed this show. I'd recommand it to anyone who knows he doesn't hate moe. Some people hate it with a passion and think moe is cancer, but hey. if you're not one of those guys/girls, watch it. And if you're new to this whole genre, start with this. It's an excellent show with the most adorable moments you'll ever see. Plus if you're tired of all the oppai-fanservice in anime lately, try moe-fanservice. It's harmless and adorable.

Very great show if you are a shoujo fan! Unfortunately, I don't believe there is an English dub for this anime; however, the sub is very cute and very appealing. 
Story- Wasn't terrible; however, it did not follow a main plot...
Art- Very warm, whimsical color scheme!! Very nice art style in my opinion!
Sound- Very warm, and adorable voice actors that were able to pull off each character!
Character- Very humorous characters! 
Enjoyment- Very nice for binge watching for small "12 episode" watchers! Very nice though!
Overall- This has a nice story line with amazing characters, and a very nice feel! I give this a 9/10 rating...
*Because ofof the art style, it may not appeal to a lot of people; however, if you liked the art style for the anime "Lucky Star", this is has similar art style!*

Warning possible Spoilers
You know it's a rare thing finding Tsundere's that actually pull off being cute and luckily this is one of those anime's that does just that.
The story centres around Tsumiki Miniwa and Io Otonashi who are best friends, but Tsumiki has a crush on Io and can't get the courage to tell him and it helps even less that he is really dense too, so along with their other friends this show tells you about their day to day live's.
Now this is one of those anime's that doesn't really have an end goal with it's story since it mainly tells it through randomintervals, but for a show like this it fit's because not every anime needs to have a strong or complex plot to get it going so instead Acchi Kocchi relies on it's characters, the mischief they make and of course Tsumiki's adorableness to keep the show going and honestly it wasn't that bad there was definitely enjoyable moments like the constant teasing within the group of characters which was always funny to see, they also play a lot games that have a lot of twists to them like the snowball fight and one game where they had to knock the other teams can away which was also entertaining to watch, they also pull a good number of pranks on each other too like for example when Mayoi was dressed up as a bear and went around scaring people which probably created a lot of memes, but was funny nonetheless.


The characters were a pretty enjoyable bunch considering there was a good number of them, but for a group of characters most of them had something that set them apart like for example Tsumiki was a Tsundere, Io was the dense male MC, Mayoi was a very eccentric person well considering she wore a lab coat and made a bunch of weird devices, Hime who was the shy person of the group and there Sakaki who was Io's best male friend.

I generally thought these characters worked well together they were funny and at times mainly because of Tsumiki were pretty adorable.


The artstyle for this show is pretty much common place for anime's that concentrate on the cute aspect which is where the characters heads are round and not the V shape that is commonly seen in most anime's so it was a nice change for once and the characters well mostly the female characters were small very small hell the teacher is practically the same size as the other female students, but the male characters all seem taller which felt pretty weird.


There is Romance in this show although don't expect something spectacular in the end, but I really liked the relationship between Tsumiki and Io it's another one of those that I can add to the cute collection because these two were adorable especially when their friends would tease them and whenever Tsumiki gets jealous or blushes was such a cute site to see.


Overall I thought this was a decent show if you're someone who likes those cute type anime's then this the right show for you, but if you are big Romance lover then you might find something here just don't expect much by the end.

First of all: KAWAII OVERLOAD!!!
Story- there was no over arching story. I was kind of hoping for one similar to the first season of to love ru. This is neither a bad thing or a good thing in my mind but there wasn't really a story. And there's no kiss. That's my big criteria for a romance slice of life, that make or break. I really enjoyed the circle things they used to separate stories kind or made me think of the 4 panel manga it was based off of. 
Art- Average, passable, Cute. I didn't really like the main male Character design but it'snothing to complain over. 


Sound- literally either the best or second best ive heard. I listened to the op and ending song every time. I even found myself trying to sing it (badly). Cute lyrics and catch tune. 


Characters-- pretty much every MC reminded me of another MC from other shows. The characters are wonderful to watch even if this does feel like a Japan equivalent of sponge bob. 


Enjoyed this to pieces. Looking for a collectors set and LE because it deserves a home.

The main sell of Acchi Kocchi is its cuteness. 
I won’t deny that there are cute scenes but unfortunately I am allergic to cats. 
Thus cute cat scenes are not affective for me. I don’t dislike cats but I’ve been conditioned to be cold to cats due to my biological factor. 
So the question is what else does this show have for someone who is allergic to the main concept?
Acchi Kocchi format is of a gag show. 
I have had many conversations in the past about the lack of progression in gag shows.
My opponents comeback with the argument that if their was more plot thanit would ruin the show.\n
I have not been convinced on that. I don’t see why gag shows still can’t have progression. Even if only a little bit per episode. \n
There is nothing different in the relationship between Tsumiki and Io from episode 1 to episode 12. It is a shame because they are a nice couple. \n\n
Gag shows are also very side character oriented \n
If the main characters are lacking in progression than it is the side characters that need to step up to keep you entertained. \n
You don’t get that with Acchi. Besides Mayoi, whom could be argued as the best character in the show, everyone else is rather insignificant. \n
One is only there to nosebleed, one is just there to be the insignificant second male, and the other three….well there isn’t really anything to say about them. \n
There isn’t that really annoying character though like the bird in Tamako Market. Acchi Kocchi has that going for it. \n\n
My conclusion is that beyond the cute cat moments there isn’t much else here on why it would be advantageous for someone to watch this show. \n
The characters are average, the story is pretty nonexistent, and the art style does provide some entertainment. \n
I do like little touches like at the end of the episode it shows off the movement to the next episode like were moving from level to level. That is basically the biggest progression of the show. \n
My final score would be a 6 out of 10. I’m unsatisfied with the other elements but I can’t find any annoyances or faults to knock the show down to a 5. \n
If your man motive was a romance anime going into the show, I could see a drop to a 5 though. \n

Acchi Kocchi Review (Tagged SPOILERS ramble only at the end of the review)
Introduction
	 Acchi Kocchi is a slice of life school romcom where romance means "unspoken love".
Music
 	OP: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0bMjtNnsA6Y
	The opening is Acchi de Kocchi de or Over There, Over Here. It's sung by the main characters of the anime and it's one of the cutest anime openings in existence. If you don't smile while listening to it you have no soul.
	 ED: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4hxxgf7lIIc
	The ending is Te o Gyu Shite ne or Grasp My Hand. It's sung by Rumi Ookubo who voices Miniwa. It's a solo song and like the beginning opening it's cute as heck.The voice actor has a very pretty voice in the endearing sense. It makes me feel all warm and fuzzy. While it's not the best ending, I love it. I would sit and listen to it at the end of every episode.


Animation


	The animation is very cute. The backgrounds and foregrounds are charming, simple and are ultimately just a means to make the main characters stand out more. All the characters are cute, unique and colourful. I love them all. They're almost chibi and sometimes even drawn in chibi for certain moments. The show uses the familiar spirals, blue lines, floral patterns and bubbles type backdrops to denote the characters moods along with their expressions. Both main characters have "ahoge" or hair antennae. Miniwa has cat ears and a tail sometimes, which is never addressed or explained as I recall. : - )


Characters


        Io Otonashi: Glasses, intelligent (OBVIOUSLY; HE HAS GLASSES) inspiration to all gentleman.

The difference between Otonashi and the generic male lead is he's so smart he knows she loves him the whole time and you see the reasons why he chooses not to confess. It's not because he doesn't want to ruin what they have, it's because he's happy with the way things are. Them being in love. Her loving him. Him knowing it and loving her back.

       Tsukimi Miniwa: Loli, runner for cutest anime character ever, shy, a bit dumb sometimes.

I love this character more than my own mother, which is saying a lot. Tsumiki Miniwa is quite possibly THE cutest anime girl. A girl as cute as her doesn't even need to be endearing, but she is. How she acts, around Otonashi especially, will make you love her even more. She's willing to go to amazing lengths just for him. In the words of How I Met Your Mother she's a "dobler". At times she's the very definition of doing and thinking crazy, fanatical things but coming off as charming.

"The Dobler-Domer theory: If both parties like each other mutually, a romantic gesture becomes 'charming,' but if only one person likes the other, the same romantic gesture becomes 'creepy'"

        The rest of the main characters: Hime Haruno, Mayoi Katase and Sakaki Inui are Otonashi and Miniwa's friends (no love triangles here(THANK GOD)). They're there for comedy and some side plot. Each of them is wonderful. Hime is there to say dumb things and nosebleed at all the ridiculous cute things Miniwa does, Mayoi is there for crazy klutz comedy, and Sakaki is there to be Otonashi's a little bit pervy joking friend, while Otonashi himself is the straight man. That's one thing I have to applaud the show for doing; taking 5 characters, making them loveable and a valuable part to the show, and not adding anymore. The formula is perfect.


Story


	Being told over years of the character's high school lives and being a slice of life and romance anime; you pretty much know what you're getting. School life, cooking, sports, snowball fights, cleaning the pool, mountain vacation, summer festival, school festival, christmas, new years, valentines, white day, and a bunch of shenanigans in between. Just teenagers having fun in their daily lives and their relationships with each other. Some of the story has to do with Otonashi and Miniwa's unspoken love. Usually when her and Otonashi are together Miniwa has these thought bubble cutscenes that play through her mind of what she wants to do with Otonashi. Quite often something like holding his hand and in her head she's saying "Just hold his hand. TAKE INITIATIVE." it drives a lot of the scenes into her getting flustered. It's the endearing part I was talking about. It also made me think long and hard about what shy girls might be thinking when I'm not taking the initiative. :P


Negatives/Positives


	To me this anime is flawless. There are no negatives at all. And there are more than enough positives to add up to a 10/10 in all I've mentioned.


Conclusion


	Acchi Kocchi is one of the greatest anime of all time.

Best moment of Acchi Kocchi, why Otonashi is so amazing, why his and Miniwa's love is so amazing, and why I think the ending was perfect:

        The best series of moments in the anime is the ones where she's waiting outside in the cold for him PRETENDING TO BUMP INTO HIM every morning so they can walk to school together. At one point he's late you see him run up to where she's still waiting despite him being late and he says "sorry for making you wait" and she blushes embarassed he knew she had been waiting for him every day. It is THE MOST heartwarming romance I've ever seen. Enough to warm my whole body in the cold of winter. The whole anime has the main characters Otonashi and Miniwa caring for each other in a show of love stronger than any other school-life romance anime I've seen. Otonashi is the very definition of a gentleman, letting Tsumiki take their relationship at her own pace. This man's patience is ridiculous. AND HE'S PERFECT THROUGHOUT THE WHOLE ANIME. NO DRAMA. And always says the right thing to put Miniwa's anxious worries to rest. He's an inspiration. They don't even call each other by their first names for the majority of the anime! But when they reach that relationship milestone and she FINALLY calls him Io and he calls her Tsumiki. It makes you feel good for years. I feel good thinking about it now. After tagging along with this group of high school students there's an indeterminate end, like most anime. It ends on an episode that's just like any other. You don't know if they ever date, or get married. But to me, unlike other anime where you're mad they haven't confessed, it was the perfect ending. You know they love each other. You know they'll be together forever. And for goodness sake they're still young. They don't need to rush into anything!

I don't consider myself a hipster (I don't have enough of a social life, plus I have a cowboy hat instead of a fedora), but there are quite a few popular anime (and other media) that I don't like. Most of the time I can understand their popularity (SAO is an energetic battle shonen romp that appeals strongly to all the gamers; Nisekoi appeals to those of us who can't get enough of love dodecahedrons, and features Shinbo and co. dressing things up with Shaft eye candy; Kiniro Mosaic can ease the stress of a long day at work or school with good clean yuricooing).


Acchi Kocchi, meanwhile, is one of those rare, brain-damaged birds whose popularity I just don't get. I mentioned Nisekoi above. One could argue that such a bland, paint-by-numbers romcom setup NEEDED the Mado/gatari team behind it to offset the insipid story. Meanwhile with Acchi Kocchi we go almost as far as physically possible in the opposite direction, with chibi mode seemingly being the main appearance of the characters; when extra humor is called for, they practically turn into plastic board game pieces, with possibly less definition than your average chess piece. The rest of the artwork isn't much better, with the background being absent for what seems like half the time.


And the story... I called Nisekoi insipid? Acchi Kocchi makes that look like quantum mechanics. ...Okay, it is rather unique to have a shy couple already an item without any drama. But that's the problem. There is almost no drama in this show. Jerry Seinfeld was wrong; slice-of-shows aren't completely about nothing. Each episode of those shows, or one of the in-episode sketches, has a character working toward some goal, however small (ie Osaka in Azumanga Daioh trying to find a hiccup cure; Renge in Non Non Biyori learning to ride a bike). With Acchi Kocchi, most scenes are simply based on a shy boy and girl trying to talk to each other or sneak off only to be interrupted by their one-note, brutally loud "friends" who seem to have been designed based on Wacky Waving Arm-Flailing Inflatable Tube Men and desperately want to watch them make out. Of course, as boy and girl are one-note kuuderes, not even the hardest liquor in Gen Urobuchi's cabinet could convince me that these two could ever so much as hold hands. Except for the WWAFITM's mentioned above, the cast, the general mood, heck, even the BGM all seem to be on extra-strength Valium. Coupled with the bargain-basement animation and character design, Acchi Kocchi almost seems more like one of those five-minute kiddie productions instead of a prime-time television anime. Yes, Kiniro Mosaic's general shtick isn't much better, but at least they put a little more effort into character design and artwork.


So yeah, I really don't get why this bit of...sloth is so highly rated and regarded. Between it, Kiniro Mosaic, and SAO, it makes me a bit worried for the future of Japanese animation.

There is really only one word to describe this - CUTE! ( oh and probably also funny. Maybe a tad romantic? oh well)
Straight from the first episode, you will entranced by this series, and you WILL be wishing for more. 
The art and sound has a distinct soft quality, but it suits the anime well, and is very well designed. There isn't really much of a storyline, but is made up of alot of small and funny sketches based around one whole premise, much like shows such as Seitokai no Ichizon and Seitokai Yakuindomo. 
Characters are slowly developed, and you can expect to slowly learnabout each of their personalities and traits. \n

Acchi Kocchi is an unique anime that blends romantic comedy and slice of life really well. It folds around a group of five high schoolers who live in an everyday life full of activities and surprises. The story mainly focuses between the two main characters of the series, Tsumiki and Io, and their close and embarrassing moments together.
Story --- 8
Acchi Kocchi is an episodic show. It doesn't follow a main objective unlike other anime. It focuses on the gang's humorous excursions and activities that they make out of their everyday lives.
Art --- 9
The art is vividly cute and light hearted giving the audience a cuteand joyful floating feeling. It's really simple and wonderfully presented. You wouldn't get bored and gloomy with the art.\n\n
Sound --- 9\n
The sound used and presented are accurately displayed. The character voices are assigned properly. The music used really blends with the mood of the scene depicted. Both the art and music really coordinates and blends well with each other.\n\n
Character --- 8\n
The characters depicted are pretty much clichés in today's standard. We have the two focused main characters: Io, a blockhead who's oblivious to love and Tsumiki, a tsundere. Character development is also really slow but that's what makes it enjoyable.\n\n
Enjoyment --- 8\n
I really enjoyed the series. It really has good sense of humor blending slice of life references. It reminds me of the fun times I have with my friends and the pranks that we made.\n\n
Overall, I give this anime a rating of 8.  The series never fails to amuse me with their slapstick romantic comedy. If you want to watch some cute characters revolving some mishaps and comedic trials then give Acchi Kocchi a  try.

This is your common RomCom that has no specific plotline, mostly comedy but there is much more to that than meets the eye. I doubted the series during the first episode however as I watched the rest, it seems that this "senseless" style of anime is actually entertaining and is a must watch for those who have a knack for Comedy and Tsunderes. Its also something that made me watch the whole series all over again just because of the comedy and in my opinion is comedy gold.

Acchi Kocchi is a very simple slice of life anime. Don't expect a lot plot because it's almost non existent in this show. It's a show about a group of 5 friends just interacting with each other and living their student lives/ The show however do focus more on the relationship between our two lovers Tsumiki Miniwa and Otonashi Io.  Tsumiki the main heroine is a kitten-like-sometimes-tsundere-cute-girl who is shy about showing her true feelings to Io (the silent type, perfect and cool guy who always looks after Tsumiki). Their feelings for each other are kinda obvious early on (Tsumiki's shyness and Io beingdense are what holds them back from being real lovers) and it just kinds of develop throughout the series.


Side characters are okay, they consistently show up and have substantial amount of screen time each episode (specially the 3 other members of the group). Mayoi Katase the resident mad scientist will give you good laughs by her weird and funny behavior and her equally outrageous inventions, Inui Sakaki the other male in the group is kinda your typical male character, a pervert who loves challenging Io to games and lastly Haruno Hime the nose bleeding loyal supporter who just can't get enough of Io and Tsumiki's cute relationship. Don't expect a lot from this show, it's a slice-of-life romance comedy (with very light plot, almost the same things happen each episode) that'll give you some laughs here and there and if you dig the romance between Io and Tsumiki you'll enjoy this. If you don't like light romance better avoid this because the comedy isn't that plentiful and you might find yourself bored for some stretches of this show.


My Personal Rating: 7/10

Well, where do I start?
It made me squeal.
Nononono
okay,
This anime is the type of anime that has almost every good genre mixed into it.
Romance
Comedy
Friendship
And the part that I love out of everything.
Awesome ass characters!
Including all the randomness that happens with them.
Here in this anime we have a good group of friends. They're all in high school now, thinking of their future and who they want to be. Of course, they don't really make that the main thing about it.
But let's get to the point here.
This anime is all about romance, let's admit that.
The whole reason why they're all there is because of those two characters thatwanna bond together.


Of course, like any other cliche romance, the girl is usually the one who is deeply in love.


Now, in this anime, it may give you clues about how the guy feels but... you can never be so sure, sadly.


It's an anime that makes you all happy, makes you laugh horribly, and makes you smile intensely.


It should, anyways.


I love everything about this anime except for one thing....


I know that many people might not mind like I do, but this is a personal opinion.


I'm not very fond of the pace.


You know those shows where the WHOLE thing is all about how they meet and how they try to confess and all that and it takes maybe three seasons for them to finally notice each other or something?


And you know those shows where you suffer with something like that and when they finally admit they love each other and they become a couple...


The show ends?


YES, I HATE THAT TOO!


Imagine, just suffering through the whole thing, and then in the end they don't even show the development... even though that was really all we damn wanted...


I mean, this anime, you can deal with it.

The whole process is very adorable and sometimes you're happy that it doesn't end.


But you have to admit... You want to see them together and who want to see that development and how they deal with it.


All that drama and adventure of jealousy or long distance, we want that.


You know you do.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


The whole point is that, yes, this anime is amazing and I do recommend it. It will make you all happy.


Though it will remind you of forever alone... and I know some of you, like me, are pretty damn forever alone.


This anime is amazing, if you haven't seen it, please do, you won't regret it.


Unless you're into the whole, "Get to the point" thing, than... it might be a little frustrating.


And yes I do know...  I do hope that there will be another season, if there isn't, I will die.

~~~~~~~~~


Either way~ Thanks a lot for reading and I hope you enjoyed this little review..

This is my first time doing this so cut me some slack.

Thank you~~~! ^-^ -Potato Chan

Place-to-place. Its title speak for itself.
Story: 7/10
It is a series that is not focused on a particular story, there is random plot,
as what it portrays, one episode is composed of 2 sets of random stories in which tells how the characters interact with each other and their environment. In the story, there are no elements of a plot, no climax, no denouement, no rising action it was just laid out there as it was told in a straightforward yet refreshing manner with a dose of comedy and moe-ness aboard.This anime truly sparks in how it delivers. The story's random as the plot may seem, theway it delivers the story makes up for the comedy was well thought of,  and the number strongest weapon would be the moe element

the romance might just be a part of the moe factor.


I rated it as 7 since there is no definite story in it, but since deliverance is well thought of and the comedy is consistent it makes up for what the anime lacks. I subtracted 3 pts since it doesn't really deliver a strong emotional impact except for comedy and moe. it is just a normal story of normal lives which is actually interesting and well laid out that totally deserve the much bigger side of the coin.


I mean, a well-made story should have made the impact of bringing charm to viewers, for example, ideologies or arguments that the viewers might realize while watching the film, but since the story is made to be random, or made to be for moe and comedic purposes, the value one might get in it is  can be taken its comedic verses and simple dialogs and not really in the story itself.


It was not your average story, it was artistically made, in a way that it can entertain and give you laughing points to ponder in its randomness. A  lighthearted slice of life story that doesn't have a plot line yet it is capable of giving a good laugh and feels in its randomness.



Animation: 10/10


I gave the animation a perfect score since it was simple and light, the characters are made to be in chibiforms it was not too colorful nor too dull, it was well balance and gives off the perfect atmosphere for the show.

 in its simplicity comes its beauty, the characters are drawn in a way that not too detailed yet would actually stand out, it is not the normal ones which makes you give the boorring vibe, it is drawn in way you can be entertained just by looking at them the artistic elements of lines and arrows, the concept of fore ground and background and the light hues definetely gives of a good balance in animation.


Sound: 10/10


I gave it a perfect score since the quality of sound definitely complements the animation. as much as the art is well balanced and smooth, the voice actors did an awesome job in voicing the characters. The tone value totally contributes in the moe feeling, it makes use of slangs portrayed in the cutest way possible.

the opening and ending song totally suits the anime, i believe the opening theme was sung by tsumiki's and io's voice actors. The opening song totally gives you the opening feeling for the show, and the ending song is perfect in terms of toning everything down.


Characters: 7/10


I gave it an 7 since each of the character presented in the story are all gives off their own charm. It is because of the character's built archetypes and personalities that brings about the colors of the anime. The story, in its essence is presented in an almost straightforward manner that it might have been too boring if there are bland characters.  Each character presents its own interesting and lively side of them that brings about the fun in the series as well as give us an enough dose of laugh about  randomness in their crazy mannerisms and ideologies. It is in its characters that the show wins its points but then at the same time, it is not perfect in its bravado nature. The characters lack depth and development. Just as the show entirely advocate their fun by means of randomness and moe comedy, the characters are not set to the path of developing and nurturing change in personality as the series progresses. In their personas, the characters in the series lack the very essence of being a character, if the characters would be the trees, it could be said that they lack roots that are planted steadily in the ground. The characters are charming at most parts, but they can have a pint of imperfection in them. 


Enjoyment: 10/10

Is it just me?  Because if you ask me what have I gained most of this show , I would say it is enjoyment. This show might just be simply made for fun and entertainment purposes and not so much on becoming a deep drama story about rescuing nakamas and fighting villains in all their wickedness in all its ideology, philosophy, and psychology in it. I had a great laugh and have a great deal of butterflies floating in my stomach and electric shock coming every now and then. This show is a real gem in comedy, as well as randomness. The art and sound I can say, is original and simple which can also contribute to the enjoyment factor. The characters are very entertaining in their own way, one would never get bored of alternately dealing with each character. One thing would suddenly pop up and become funny before you know it, you are laughing and getting the feels as the episode was already wrapping up. I enjoyed it much. 


Overall: would be the value of the average of all the scores added up.

When I first heard about this show, I thought it was just some lame, school life moe bait cliche, where they would just use 48 "cute", identical girls that look like their eye sockets are roughly the same size as their rib cage. But boy was I wrong.

Oh my. You have no idea how many times I died watching this series. Its tooooo cute! Its tooo moe!! I FREAKIN’ LOVE IT!!!
Acchi Kocchi was indeed a shocker. The story follows the everyday life of Tsumiki and her very dense yet really kind crush, Io, along with their fellow classmates and peers. This anime is a simple highschool anime that has slice-of-life, comedy, a bit of romance & a gallon full of cuteness under its belt. I was expecting this to be the typical ones that we usually see nowadays, but oh boy I’m wrong. The level of comedy in this anime doesn’t reachthe heights of Konosuba or Monthly Girl’s Nozaki-kun, but its more subtle and easy to digest on. What made it funny is the fact that their jokes were really mundane and it could definitely happen in real life, insert the slice-of-life elements of the series. They do exaggerate the reactions to the circumstances, still, the level of relatability is sky high. Well, this is just my opinion though.


What made this series really fun to watch was the characters and their cutene–I mean…their interactions with each other. They are definitely highschool kids, they act like one, they enjoy their school life like one. Except for the ‘simple’ traits like Tsumiki’s cat-like appearance or Mayoi’s prowess in technology, all the characters are very close to a human beings in real life. I really want to point out how amazing the relationships of the characters are with one another. Each one of them compliments and even counteract conversations and arguments with one another. I LOVE THAT. I can’t help but smile in everything they do.


Another thing that made me really really like this series is the fact that THEY ARE FREAKIN’ CUTE!!! AND MOE!! Oh Mhay Ghad!!! This series is ssooooooo ccccuuuutttteee! Damn, I’m getting diabetes watching this show. Theart & animation is soooo my type. I really really like the art of the series, its so consistent and the color palette all through out the series was soothing in the eyes. It never bored me. The animation though. Dunno if its because my copy is a BD but damn its soooooo consistent and rich…I can’t. The animation could go head to head with any animes in the same genre, and damn Acchi Kocchi would still win. Its that gooooooooddddd.


The music & sound is also cute very fitting to the series. The OP was sung by the casts. I am not much of a fun of songs like this (sang by the casts) but damn this OP sure is hella cute, but I am also sure I don’t want this to be on repeat on my phone. The ED was…cute…but not my type of ED song.


Overall, this series gave me life. The level of cuteness, and lightheartedness could give anyone a disease. A disease of happiness…for days. Its a must watch on my book. This anime is recommended to people who likes to watch animes with the elements of moe, school theme, slice-of-life, subtle comedy, and a pinch of romance. This anime doesn’t disappoint.


Anyway, that is all folks.


Thanks for reading!!

Acchi Kocchi represents a critical dilemma within me. I love (more than I would care to admit) romantic comedies, yet I place a very large emphasis on a strong plot. For those who have watched other similar rom-coms, you most likely understand why this can be a problem. Most shows of this nature (barring a small number of rare exceptions) have absolutely no story, and rather try to create entertaining character interactions and poignant scenes to fill the void. This sometimes works, but often times the result is so bland, so boring, and so contrived, that it leaves you with a sour taste in yourmouth. Unfortunately, this is exactly how I would describe the trainwreck that is Acchi Kocchi, or Place to Place.


Know that this review is coming from an avid consumer of mediocre high school rom-coms, so when I say this show is bad, it's really bad. To detail my distaste for this  anime's story, there will be one paragraph containing minor spoilers. I don't think anyone should put themselves through the hell that is this show, but if you are for some reason interested in the show, skip the second paragraph of the story section.


STORY - 2/10


As previously stated, many, if not most rom-coms look to crafting quirky and/or funny interactions between its characters to substitute for a lack of plot. Acchi Kocchi definitely attempts to do this, but given the cookie-cutter cast of walking anime tropes, any conversations between characters can only be seen as drab, and boring. The pace is slow, and the episodes drag on as they go. Every adventure that the characters go on has been done in practically every other 


The next section contains minor "spoilers" so you can skip it if you'd like. There isn't anything even mildly unique in the story, so if you've been exposed to any sort of romantic media at all, you can definitely guess the plot, so it shouldn't be a problem. But if you still don't want any "spoilers", you can skip the next section. I apologize if this takes up a majority of the story section.

                                                                                                                                                                 ** MINOR SPOILERS**


The main problem that I had with the story of Acchi Kocchi was the romantic build-up, and then the absolute lack of payoff. You can read the synopsis, but the first eleven episodes essentially portrays romance growing between the two protagonists, to the extent that it's pretty blatantly shown that they both like each other. Mind you there is one episodes left. NOTHING HAPPENS IN THE LAST EPISODE. Anyone with a brain would expect to see some sort of confession, some sort of declaration of love, anything. Even the worst of rom-coms have the common sense to have this payoff. Somehow the writers thought it would be a good idea to destroy the (albeit minimal) momentum that they had built. The last episode acts as  if the characters were normal platonic classmates. This was probably the most infuriating ending that I've watched of any anime. I cannot imagine any competent person writing the garbage that was the last episode.


Another problem I had with the story were the side-characters. There were two characters in particular that had a romance of their own building up. This may just be me reading between the lines too much, but there were a number of signs showing that the writers were trying to create said romance, yet there was  still no payoff whatsoever. They remained platonic friends till the end. This had the potential to be really good relationship, but in their usual incompetency. The writers did absolutely nothing to make the relationship tangible.

                                                                                                                                                                                         **END SPOILERS**


Basically, the story sucks. It in itself is a reason not to watch the show. The only reason that I give it a three is because of 1) The minimal buildup of the first 11 episodes 2) there were very few funny moments, but when they were funny they were really funny.


ART - 5/10


The art is as the score describes  it. There isn't anything good about it, it's  just average. Call me nitpicky, but I thought it was pretty odd how Miniwa's hair literally changed colors randomly. Sometimes it was blue, sometimes it was indigo. I also don't understand the design of Mayoi. While I know it's pretty standard to have character's whose eyes you can't see, I still dislike the idea.


SOUND - 5/10


While the art is average, the sound is just a bit below average. While I thoroughly enjoy OPs and EDs sung by the cast, this one wasn't done very well. The seiyuus didn't sing well, and it sounded extremely childish. There isn't a single OST track that stuck with me, and I'd be hard-pressed to name one that was particularly fitting for the mood.


CHARACTER - 3/10


As mentioned above, all of the characters followed a common trope. Miniwa was the tsundere, Io was the nerdy yet somehow palpitation-inducing protagonist, Mayoi was the genki girl who tried to set up Miniwa and Io, Hime was the klutsy, yet endearing girl. Sakaki was Friend A. You get the point. While following these cliches doesn't necessitate characters devoid of personality, they unfortunately ended up as such. No one had a shred of characterization, and all of the reactions, conversations, and jokes could have been predicted twenty minutes prior.


ENJOYMENT - 4/10


While I'm extremely critical of this show, I can't say that I didn't enjoy it all. Like I said earlier, I'm an avid consumer of rom-coms, whether I like it or not. I still felt a slight (emphasis on slight) tug at the heart during romantic moments between Miniwa and Io, and I still chuckled (not a full laugh, just a chuckle) at the funny moments. The ending sucked out my soul, and made me hate the show, but the first eleven episodes were good enough to make me feel the standard set of emotions when watching rom-coms. 


OVERALL - 4/10


There are a lot of bad things about Acchi Kocchi. A lot. I could never recommend this anime with good conscious, but I still have to acknowledge that there isn't NOTHING that's good. The main shortcoming of the show is it's disgusting ending, and complete lack of uniqueness. But, those like me who thoroughly school rom-coms can still gain something (but not very much at all) from watching the show. It still pulls off the standard events with subpar proficiency.
